channel.title: Client user ID upon reconnect, need clarification
channel.description:
If the client reconnects using status code 18, does it send the same user ID it sent upon initial login?
I assume yes because that's the only practical use the user id would have.
EDIT: for the people maintaining the RS Wiki, at stage 3 of the login protocol there is 1 byte missing after "client version" the client also sends another byte indicating if the client is lowmem or highmem

item.title: Client user ID upon reconnect, need clarification
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

that explains that, Thanks for the info

item.source: Client user ID upon reconnect, need clarification

item.title: Client user ID upon reconnect, need clarification
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:6, topic:554665”]the name hash serves no function whatsoever.

so say you’re running 2 clients at once, do they use the same uid?[/quote]

iirc the name hash is used to determine a login server but that is irrelevant.

[code=java]
private static int getUid(String prefix) {
try {
File uid = new File(prefix + “uid.dat”);
if (!uid.exists() || uid.length() < 4) {
try (DataOutputStream os = new DataOutputStream(new FileOutputStream(prefix + “uid.dat”))) {
os.writeInt((int) (Math.random() * 99999999));
}
}
} catch (IOException ex) {
}

	try (DataInputStream is = new DataInputStream(new FileInputStream(prefix + "uid.dat"))) {
		return is.readInt() + 1;
	} catch (IOException ex) {
		return 0;
	}
}[/code]

UID is cached locally in a file named uid.dat (random.dat in newer clients), so unless you explicitly change this then yes the UID of two clients on the same machine would be the same

Read full topic

item.source: Client user ID upon reconnect, need clarification

item.title: Client user ID upon reconnect, need clarification
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:4, topic:554665”]the only user id that is discussed and documented in the rs2 login protocol on the rs wiki <_<

The uid usually doesn’t change the only exception is client hacking, bad programming, glitchy weirdness, or if you change it manually.

Its a very bad old security system before rsa to make sure only your client could connect to your server because you set the uid on both supposedly preventing cheat clients or clients with extra features like noclip.

So the uid only changes per new connection the client makes? Am I better off just ignoring it then?[/quote]

Yeah but you posted in server help…

Also user id could mean the name hash as well as the randomly generated uid.

The uid you’re speaking of is generated if one does not already exist (random.dat) and that is the same until the uid is deleted.

Read full topic
